physical_appearance:This walking stick has small decorative inlays with carved stylized crosses along its body. At the top of the walking stick
 there is a silver finial in the shape of a ball
 with some ringed decorative elements. There are slight scratches along the body of the stick.
subject_terms_1:crosses (motifs) souvenirs

 canes
 etc.) Souvenirs (Keepsakes) Motifs
subject_terms_3:Decorative arts
sgcool_label_text:This walking stick is inscribed with the name of the city of Vigan
 a significant port in the North of the Phillippines. It is dated 1882
 when the city was controlled by a Spanish colonial government.  It bears the name Francisco Carlos Corrales
 a Spaniard who must have bought it or received it as a gift or momento. He probably brought it back with him to Spain where it remained for over a century. Given the fine materials and workmanship it clearly was meant for the use of a wealthy gentleman.

metadata.materials_name: horn (animal material) ivory (material) silver (metal) mother of pearl
metadata.physical_appearance: This walking stick has small decorative inlays with carved stylized crosses along its body. At the top of the walking stick, there is a silver finial in the shape of a ball, with some ringed decorative elements. There are slight scratches along the body of the stick.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: This walking stick is inscribed with the name of the city of Vigan, a significant port in the North of the Phillippines. It is dated 1882, when the city was controlled by a Spanish colonial government.  It bears the name Francisco Carlos Corrales, a Spaniard who must have bought it or received it as a gift or momento. He probably brought it back with him to Spain where it remained for over a century. Given the fine materials and workmanship it clearly was meant for the use of a wealthy gentleman.
